newsitem.title: USA: CSCE world sugar ends up after test of support.
newsitem.headline: CSCE world sugar ends up after test of support.

text.p: CSCE world sugar futures closed higher after the benchmark October contract failed to erode support and attracted short-covering and fund buying, dealers said.
The front month eased to the recent low of 11.55 cents amid aggressive origin pricing. Short-covering by the trade blocked further losses and brought in speculative buying in the afternoon.
"Everyone got a bit too short, the selling dried up and the specs took it higher," a sugar broker said.

The October contract is seen trading in a range from the contract high of 11.78 to 11.55 cents a lb in the near term, but Friday's Commitment of Traders report could give traders an incentive to break out of that range.
The market expects the report to reveal that the speculators are holding a more than 50 percent net long position.
"It would shake a lot of nerves if the net long position is smaller," the broker said.
The next downside target was pegged at 11.40-11.20 cents basis October.
The October contract closed 0.10 cent higher at 11.68 cents a lb, having ranged from 11.70 to 11.55 cents. The outer months settled 0.02 to 0.10 cent higher.
An estimated 15,494 lots changed hands on the day compared with Wednesday's official 19,510 lots.
Open interest in October fell by 704 lots to 112,280 lots as of early Wednesday.
